title: England in sensational start as fans gather to watch semi-final against New Zealand
text:
England fans ahead of the 2019 Rugby World Cup semi-final match at International Stadium Yokohama (Picture: PA)

England and New Zealand fans have gathered to watch the two nations do battle in the Rugby World Cup semi-finals.

Supporters came together both in the UK and over in Japan where the tournament is taking place.

Fans over here had to be up early to catch the momentous clash for a spot in the final, with England making a great start and taking a 10-0 lead into half-time.

Manu Tuilagi scored a try after just 97 seconds and England used their heavyweight ball-carrying forwards to considerable effect.

England fans enjoy themselves ahead of the game (Picture: PA)

England fans are hoping for a win (Picture: PA)

England thought they had increased their lead in the 25th-minute when flanker Sam Underhill sprinted over New Zealand’s line unopposed.

Referee Nigel Owens checked with television match official Marius Jonker, though, and the score was ruled out for Tom Curry crossing in front of a New Zealand player during build-up play.

It was a let-off for the All Blacks as England continued to impress and superb work led to a penalty just before half-time, which George Ford put between the posts leaving the score 10-0 at half-time.

England fans enjoy the pre-match atmosphere in Yokohama Stadium (Picture: Getty)

England fans in Japan (Picture: PA)

Fans show their support during the Rugby World Cup 2019 semi-final match (Picture: Getty)

Defending champions New Zealand are favourites but many still hope England can cause an upset.

New Zealand haven’t lost a World Cup game since a quarter-final defeat to France in 2007, and are aiming for an unprecedented third consecutive title.

They take a six-game winning streak against England into the semi-final and no other team has won two World Cups in a row.

Fans watch England v New Zealand in London (Picture: Reuters)

Fans watch England take the lead (Picture: Reuters)

It was a great half for England (Picture: Reuters)

New Zealand players perform a haka (Picture: Getty)

Manu Tuilangi of England crosses for the first try (Picture: Getty)

England were aiming to reach the final for the first time since 2007, when they lost to South Africa.

They were eliminated in the quarter-finals in 2011 and failed to make it out of the group stage in 2015 in the tournament they were hosting.

England’s extra-time victory over Australia in the 2003 final is the only Rugby World Cup title won by a team from the northern hemisphere.

South Africa and Wales meet Sunday in the other semi-final.
